question: A 32-year-old man jumps off a 3 story building during a suicide attempt. Paramedics arrive quickly, and he is taken to the hospital where several stable lumbar fractures and a shattered right calcaneus are found. He undergoes surgery and his calcaneus is repaired with 11 screws. Which of the following statements best describes the long term post-surgery outcome in this patient?

options.A: He will not be able to plantar flex his foot.
options.B: He will not be able to point his toe.
options.C: He will have pain with inversion and eversion of his foot.
options.D: He will have pain while dorsiflexing his foot.

The calcaneus plays a crucial role in supporting the body's weight, facilitating movements such as plantarflexion (pointing the foot downward), and absorbing shock when walking or running. A fractured calcaneus can lead to instability and pain in these movements. 3. After surgery, the patient underwent repair with 11 screws, which is a common treatment approach for severe calcaneal fractures to restore stability and promote healing. 4. Considering the anatomical function of the calcaneus and the typical outcomes of calcaneal fractures, we can evaluate the provided options: - A: Plantarflexion (pointing the foot downward) is a movement that primarily involves the gastrocnemius and soleus muscles, which are not directly affected by a calcaneal fracture. Therefore, option A is unlikely. - B: Pointing the toe is a movement that involves the metatarsal bones and the tibialis anterior muscle, which are not directly related to the calcaneus. Thus, option B is also unlikely. - C: Inversion and eversion of the foot are movements that involve the talocrural joint (ankle joint), which is connected to the calcaneus. A fractured calcaneus can lead to instability in these movements, causing pain. This option seems plausible. - D: Dorsiflexion (lifting the foot upward) is a movement that primarily involves the tibialis anterior muscle, which is not directly affected by a calcaneal fracture.
